I believe that there will be some major good news coming between now and earnings in early November. The share price will go above the 52 week high and then the company will do a small offering of additional shares. Remember our shares outstanding are less than 30 million so even if they dilute by offering lets say 5 million shares, we still only have less than 35 Million shares outstanding which is low.Full disclosure..I have 24K shares at an average of $10

if we can get follow through for a second day  here.... we are going to start perking up for Q3... time is running out quickly for the short game, I'm looking for a move back soon to $18-19 prior to Q3.... too much risk being caught off guard with a new press release prior to earnings for shorts and sellers

I'm not sure what you mean by shakedown. Folks bought in the 14's and sold in the 16's and 15's. That's what some people do, they trade this high beta stock. They do it early and often. Some even telegraph their swing trades on this MB. Long term shareholders, who aren't also trading the company, need to understand the dynamics here. Trading in Innodata is prevalent. And those who trade use the MB's to voice whatever sentiment is consistent with their desire to load when they want to load, and dump when they want to dump. This is as old as the hills.
Shakedown on low volume.

Q,Last week there were two short reports on INOD.As you can see their ability to manipulate is getting weaker and weaker.I’d like to see a 2 million share day with a two dollar plus increase.I think the time is coming where we will see that, November 7 would be a good day.

Feels like shorts are starting to cover here and there. Bleeding out slowly instead of ripping the bandaid off. They know what’s coming in 5 weeks. Still have time to take it down again for a week or two but they know the inevitable.

Blackrock owns 1.9 million shares or 6.5% of Innodata shares.  Vanguard owns 1.5 million shares or 5.1% of all shares.  Wells Fargo recently increased Innodata's line of credit to $50 million.  I tend to trust these firms and Innodata's audited financials over short JCapital's misleading report for profit or brain dead Karls worthless due diligence.
Karl is a bacteria

Innodata is a company that relies on labor forces located all over the world to gather the data that makes this engine hum. Excellent work overseas can often be done be done at a fraction of the cost to do that same work here. Harris is a globalist and believes in sustaining and strengthening our alliances, believes in global trade and global order. Trump is an isolationist that has and will do all he can to punish global trade and global order, as well as the notion of the rule of international law. Trump’s policies could make it difficult or impossible for companies like Innodata to conduct their international business, and prohibitively expensive to do so. Tax exposure to wealthy Americans will return, slowly, to pre-Trumpian levels. That’s a fact with Harris or any other Democrat. Harris will also appoint competent judiciary to further the rule of law and Trump would appoint incompetent loyalists to gut our legal system. Trump would also gut the regulatory branches of government, including the SEC, making it highly likely that shorts and other nefarious forces would further rig the system making it impossible for moms and pops like us to get a fair shake and make any money in the markets. Period. Harris believes in strengthening regulation and would do all she could to level the playing field to the benefit of all of us here.

Here is where we stand with tax policy:Kamala Harris and Biden together stated last winter that they would liketo tax long-term capital gains as "ordinary income". So, an INOD investorin a 24% tax bracket selling his stock would be taxed $2,400 instead of$1,500 for his $10,000 capital gain.But Harris/Biden also don't like Trump's 2017 tax cuts, so letting themexpire next year would turn a 24% marginal tax bracket into a 28% taxbracket and the stock sale would be taxed $2,800. That would almostDOUBLE it! Mr. Trump likes the LT gain tax right where it is at 15%.Harris/Biden have also stated that the top corporate tax rate (the one thataffects INOD the most) should be increased from 21% currently to 28%, anincrease of 33% on this company that would certainly hurt it's performanceand stock price.Mr. Trump wants to reduce the corporate rate from 21% to 15%. Like the LTgain tax proposals, Harris wants the rate almost DOUBLE what Mr. Trumpwants it to be.Harris also wants to tax un-realized gains for higher income investors.Kamala Harris has always been anti-business/anti-investor. Her presidencywould be bad for the market and bad for INOD. It's not investors like us whowould be electing her. It's people like Taylor Swift fans who have no ideawhat Harris has in mind to do to us.And it's not like Harris wants people to know. She absolutely refuses to doa news conference.

Wells Fargo $50 million line of credit, SEC filings, audited financials, no insider sales and 6 years of sales growth speaks volumes.  Wells Fargo did their due diligence in increasing Innodata's line of credit.  JCapital and lying Karl also claim they did their due diligence. JCapital report makes all sorts of claims of worldwide fraud.  If there was any fraud, Well's Fargo would not have increased the line of credit, the SEC would have already jailed Innodata's management and insiders would have all bailed at higher prices.  Who's ever heard of JCapital?  JCapital's report has disclaimers about what's in their report that's miles long.  JCapital's report is a fraud to decrease Innodata's stock price for profit.
as if anyone cares what you think bozi dgha lol

I purchased puts when the stock was around $20.  I see single digits soon.  Gosuko and Elidiot will say the same tired tune of how it's just great that you can buy it cheaper.  They'll never admit they were wrong.  People of lower IQ tend to gravitate towards each other.  This board is proof.  I don't think I'll return, though I'll enjoy my profits.  Thanks guys.

Unless and until he becomes more proactive, those guys will stay emboldened and continue to trash the company without any concern. JMHO.

A popular website seeking....  shows JCapital hasn't put out a report since the year 2018.  I've researched both reports and feel extremely confident that these report are false from beginning to end.  JCapitals website has a disclaimer a mile long regarding their false report.

How is this a "collapse"? Would you kindly pull up the two year chart, and note this was under $3 two autumns ago. I say this as respectfully as possible, kindly next pull up the one year chart, this was $6 a few months ago. No one in their right mind thought or thinks that the base is $20 here. No way. This is a fast mover, in both directions, and the float is very low (thank you Jack for being frugal and disciplined over the last two decades). That's the reason there are a lot of momentum traders, this stock has legs. I believe the future is bright. I wasn't so certain two quarters ago, but I'm more confident today than at any time in the past two decades. A handful of folks have taken some profits, which should never be criticized. The profit takers may slightly exceed the accumulators, and that will move the needle. Why take profits now? Because some are wary about the ramping up costs and potential paucity of profits in the near term. They also may perceive a softening in the AI sector and revision of some of the larger orders. Those folks are likely to continue to follow, and may re-enter at higher bases when the future is clearer. I'm not concerned, as I don't foresee a high likelihood of any negative catalysts on the horizon at the moment. Maybe a hit piece or two, but I trust that Jack will be much more proactive in combatting same.
I don't think any shareholders is happy, but it does present a buying opportunity before of and when the management reconfirms strong growth and/or announces new contracts

I’ve lived through an INOD collapse like this before and it was brutal. Hard to believe certain shareholders are actually happy when the price goes down. Makes me question their real motives. Hoping that a turnaround starts today with the Fed meeting.

Charts look fine. A little cooling in the overheated AI sector. I think the trading range for the foreseeable future is 12-24, and I think a return to the single digits is highly unlikely. This is a volatile low-float stock. The true longs know what they own. Momentum traders will come and go has been the history here since I started following. When she moves, she can really fly, and vice versa.

Things are looking good for virtually everyone. The long term perspective has never looked better for true longs. The broad trading range and high volatility/high beta looks like ongoing opportunity for the momentum traders, some of whom get impatient when behind in a trade. No true long would be unhappy with a trading range of $12 to $24, or so, for the time being. And I see very little chance of this ever dipping back to single digits. Additionally, there is the very real possibility of an upside surprise in the short term, including either a buyout or partnership. I don't think a sale price of $1B+/- is unreasonable given the uptick in revenue and the prospect of owning, exclusively, a premier high quality data engineering company, which would make for a nice division of any of our Mag 7 clients. Such an announcement could happen momentarily. You'd wake up to $33 or so. Could genuinely happen.  There also is the possibility of an acquisition, which while not without risk, should be exciting for true longs who understand the challenges of exponentially growing a small company to a much larger one. In short, there is no downside that I see for either true longs or momentum traders. This is a place to be. So, Jimbo, I agree with your sentiments. Things are looking good.

On May 8, more than 2/3 of the float turned over. 19M shares traded. There were sellers and there were buyers, and transactions were completed in the $8-$10 range. Lots of new folks entered on that date and plenty more since then. Many with little DD. People are attracted to movers, especially in the AI category. The majority of these folks are sitting on nice profits. The stock has doubled since they bought even considering today's present decline. It should surprise no one here that some newbies are taking nice profits. Whether they are wrong or right, whether they have thought it through or not as carefully as some might expect, they are locking in profits. No one should be surprised by this kind of behavior. The purpose of investing is ROI and today's sellers have nice scores. In turn, others with longer term outlooks are taking advantage of what they believe to be good entry points. This is how the markets work. Fast movers move fast in both directions.
